Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Unified Framework for the Investigation of Time Series Using Topological Data Analysis

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in sensor technology and computer hardware have led to a shift towards data-driven analysis and modeling of engineered and natural systems. The study of the resulting streams of data currently requires extensive expertise and often utilizes methods that are not guaranteed to be optimal. This leads to an overly qualitative analysis that can miss a significant portion of the information hidden within the signal. This project aims to utilize and advance tools from topological data analysis, an emergent field focused on providing quantitative measurements of the shape of data, and to elucidate invisible features and structure of signals which current methods cannot detect. Therefore, the resulting framework will be able to provide insight into the systems that generated the data while providing a strong mathematical footing for automating the analysis of systems and processes. The knowledge gained from the work will benefit a wide variety of scientific fields where analysis from sensor feedback signals is needed such as additive manufacturing and smart drug delivery systems. Furthermore, the interdisciplinary nature of this project will offer students rich opportunities for collaboration and cross-training in a variety of areas in engineering, applied math, and signal analysis. The PIs will also continue and expand their efforts to identify and recruit graduate students from under-represented groups with relevant interests by working with the Association for Women in Mathematics and the Society for Women Engineers.

This project is a collaborative effort that seeks to investigate an innovative framework for time series analysis through advancing and linking signal processing, dynamical systems, and topological data analysis. The research team will pursue a topological approach that utilizes the recently developed persistent homology to study the time series of dynamical systems. Specifically, they will (1) derive a solid mathematical foundation based on applied topology which enables a more robust and quantitative investigation of dynamical systems, (2) research innovative methods for studying the topology of the underlying manifold in dynamical systems from collected time series using topological data analysis, and (3) demonstrate and assess the validity of the theoretical results using numerical and physical experiments. The theoretical underpinning of the research is especially suitable for detecting and describing dynamical signatures such as underlying attractors, chaos, and self-similarity using lower dimensional descriptors, rather than lower dimensional representation. Therefore, this work is capable of providing a new perspective into our understanding of time series analysis particularly for dynamical systems with complex behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on utilizing and advancing tools from Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to elucidate invisible features and structure of signals which other methods could not detect. The scope of the work included systems that evolve with no randomness (called deterministic dynamical systems), and signals with measurement noise.

Intellectual Merit: This project led to a TDA-based chaos detection method, and to a new approach that combines for the first time constructions from network theory, time series, and applied topology for dynamic state detection, i.e., for determining without prior knowledge of the analyzed signal corresponds to a system with regular versus chaotic response. This work also introduced a new approach for detecting a transition from stationary response of a complex system to an oscillatory response (these transitions are called Hopf bifurcations) using a tool from TDA called Zigzag persistent homology. It also led to new tools for studying time delay systems with intrinsic randomness, for step detection in periodic, piecewise constant signals such as the signal generated by sensors that measure the step count of a person.
Other notable results include contributions to information theory through developing tools for automatically selecting the parameters needed to compute a quantity called permutation entropy from measured time series data. The project also contributed to new theory on approximating continuous functions on persistence diagrams, the flagship objects from TDA, using a framework that was coined `template functions'.

Further, as a result of this grant, the PI also provided new investigative tools for studying vibration signals collected from sensors on machining centers. Specifically, the PI described new methods for extraction information from these signal to detect whether the underlying manufacturing process is exhibiting chatter, i.e., is subject to harmful but not necessarliy obvious vibration that can damage the tool or the workpiece, or is chatter free.

Broader Impact: The project has created research opportunities for four graduate students, and five undergraduate students within the PI's group. Further, in addition to publishing the results and giving several presentations, the data, experiments, and code developed during the course of the project  are shared on public repositories with proper documentation and sufficient details to replicate the provided results, and adapt the outcomes of this work for other applications. The majority of the algorithms developed are posted on public repository with brief background information, usage information, and examples. This is expected to lower the barrier to entry for scientists and practitioners aiming to take advantage of the topologically enhanced methods for analyzing signals, and of the tools that reduce the required level of expertise and the input of the user.
